title: Post Feed || Kentucky-Florida
text:
Three takeaways from Kentucky's 88-66 loss at Florida Saturday night. 
1) Gator Bait 
Kentucky got annihilated on the glass by the Gators 54-29 and despite shooting just 37.7 percent and missing 38 shots, the Wildcats recorded just six offensive rebounds. 
That statistic, in and of itself, is indicative of a lack of effort. 
The Cats looked flat from the opening tip, falling behind early and never really mounting much offense in scoring a season low 26 first half points and 66 total points. 
Kentucky is now just 1-6 vs. Florida as part of ESPN's College GameDay. 
2) Off the Rails 
The Wildcats (18-5, 8-2 SEC) have now lost three of its last four games and are coming dangerously close to having this thing come off the rails. 
Kentucky looks nothing like the team we saw early in the season and look to be regressing in several phases of the game. 
Teams are figuring out how to slow UK down in transition and make them earn points with execution in the halfcourt, which has given this young team some problems at times. 
It's hard to say how much of an impact the sickness that has ran through the team in recent weeks has had, but either way, this team better start figuring things out in a hurry. 
3) The Defense Rests 
It wasn't as big of an issue earlier in the season because Kentucky was scoring a ton of points, but now that teams are limiting the Wildcats' fastbreak points, it's become clear that UK's defense is a liability. 
Especially given Kentucky's length, quickness and athleticism at every position, this simply does not look like the typical John Calipari-coached defensive team we've become accustomed to seeing. 
UK's last eight opponents have shot better than 40 percent from the floor, with the Gators shooting a blistering 66.7 percent in the second half Saturday night and 48.4 percent for the game. Author
